content.question: Let <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="f of x, equals, x times sine x " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> with domain <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma infinity, close parenthesis " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>∞</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. The function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has no absolute minimum and no absolute maximum on its domain. Why does this not contradict the Extreme Value Theorem?

choices.label: The domain of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is not an open interval.
The domain of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is not a closed and bounded interval.
The function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is not continuous on its domain.
The function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is not differentiable on its domain.

content.answer: The domain of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is not a closed and bounded interval.

topic.text: 5.2: Extreme Value Theorem, Global Versus Local Extrema, and Critical Points

skill.text: Skill 3.E: Provide reasons or rationales for solutions and conclusions.
